From Wiktionary, the free dictionary
See also: berber

English

[edit]
English Wikipedia has an article on:
Berber
Wikipedia

Etymology

[edit]

From Arabic بَرْبَرِيّ (barbariyy, “Berber”), from Ancient Greek βάρβαρος (bárbaros, “non-Greek, foreign, barbarian”), apparently imitative of foreign speech. Cognate of English barbarian.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • (UK) IPA(key): /ˈbɜːbə/
  • (US, Canada) IPA(key): /ˈbɝ.bɚ/
  • Audio (US):(file)
  • Rhymes: -ɜː(ɹ)bə(ɹ)

Noun

[edit]

Berber (plural Berbers or Berber)

  1. (potentially offensive, occasionally proscribed) A member of a particular ethnic group indigenous to northwest Africa.
  2. (plural only "Berbers") A kind of traditional rug manufactured by the Berber people.
    • 2009, Jean Nayar, Staged to Sell (or Keep) (page 55)
      Berbers are the best example of looped carpet […]

Usage notes

[edit]

The first sense of the term may be considered offensive. Much like the term Galla, the term “Berber” is an exonym, with “Amazigh” being preferred in most cases.

Synonyms

[edit]
  • Imazighen pl (singular: Amazigh)

Translations

[edit]
Member of northwest African ethnic group
  • Arabic: أَمَازِيغِيّ m (ʔamāzīḡiyy), بَرْبَرِيّ m (barbariyy) (now offensive sometimes, literally "Barbarian”)
  • Armenian: բերբեր (hy) (berber)
  • Catalan: berber (ca)
  • Central Atlas Tamazight: ⴰⵎⴰⵣⵉⵖ (amaziɣ), ⵉⵎⴰⵣⵉⵖⴻⵏ pl (imaziɣen)
  • Chinese:
    Mandarin: 柏柏爾 / 柏柏尔 (zh) (Bòbò'ěr)
  • Czech: Berber (cs) m
  • Danish: Berber, berber c
  • Esperanto: berbero
  • Finnish: berberi (fi)
  • French: Berbère (fr) m or f
  • German: Berber (de) m, Berberin (de) f
  • Greek: Βέρβερος (el) m (Vérveros)
    Ancient: Μάξυος m (Máxuos)
  • Hindi: बर्बर (hi) (barbar), बार्बर (hi) (bārbar)
  • Icelandic: Berberi m
  • Irish: Beirbeireach m
  • Italian: berbero (it) m, berberi (it) m pl
  • Japanese: ベルベル人 (Beruberu-jin)
  • Kabyle: amaziɣ
  • Korean: 베르베르인 (bereubereu'in)
  • Norwegian:
    Bokmål: berber m
    Nynorsk: berbar m
  • Polish: Berber (pl) m, Berberyjka (pl) f
  • Portuguese: berbere (pt) m
  • Russian: бербе́р (ru) m (berbér)
  • Serbo-Croatian:
    Cyrillic: Бѐрбер m
    Roman: Bèrber m
  • Spanish: berebere (es)
  • Swedish: berber (sv) c
  • Tarifit: amaziɣ m, tamaziɣt f, imaziɣen m pl
  • Tashelhiyt: ⴰⵛⵍⵃⵉⵢ m (aclḥiy), ⵜⴰⵛⵍⵃⵉⵢⵜ f (taclḥiyt), ⵉⵛⵍⵃⵉⵢⵏ m pl (iclḥiyn), ⵜⵉⵛⵍⵃⵉⵢⵉⵏ f pl (ticlḥiyin)
  • Turkish: Berberi (tr)
  • Vietnamese: người Berber

Proper noun

[edit]

Berber

  1. A group of closely related Afroasiatic languages spoken in northern Africa, particularly Morocco and Algeria.

Derived terms

[edit]
  • Proto-Berber

Translations

[edit]
a group of closely related languages
  • Arabic: أَمَازِيغِيَّة (ar) f (ʔamāzīḡiyya)
    Moroccan Arabic: شلحة (šelḥa)
  • Catalan: berber (ca) m, amazic (ca) m
  • Central Atlas Tamazight: ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵣⵉⵖⵜ f (tamaziɣt)
  • Chinese:
    Mandarin: 柏柏爾語 / 柏柏尔语 (Bòbò'ěryǔ)
  • Czech: berberština f
  • Danish: berbisk
  • Finnish: berberi (fi), berberikieli (fi)
  • French: berbère (fr) m
  • German: Berber (de) n
  • Irish: Beirbeiris f
  • Japanese: ベルベル語 (ja) (Beruberu-go)
  • Norwegian:
    Bokmål: berbisk m
    Nynorsk: berbisk m
  • Occitan: berbèr (oc) m
  • Portuguese: berbere (pt) m
  • Russian: бербе́рский (ru) (berbérskij)
  • Tarifit: tamaziɣt f
  • Tashelhiyt: ⵜⴰⵛⵍⵃⵉⵢⵜ f (taclḥiyt), ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵣⵉⵖⵜ f (tamaziɣt)
  • Walloon: amazir (wa)

See also

[edit]
  • Category:English terms derived from Berber languages
  • Category:Berber languages

Adjective

[edit]

Berber (not comparable)

  1. Of the Berber people, their culture, or their language.

Translations

[edit]
of the Berber people
  • Arabic: أَمَازِيغِيّ (ʔamāzīḡiyy)
  • Catalan: berber (ca), amazic (ca)
  • Czech: berberský (cs)
  • Dutch: Berbers (nl)
  • Finnish: berberi- (fi), berberien
  • French: berbère (fr)
  • Greek: βερβερικός (el) (ververikós)
  • Hindi: बर्बर (hi) (barbar), बार्बर (hi) (bārbar)
  • Icelandic: berberskur
  • Irish: Beirbeireach
  • Japanese: ベルベル人 (Beruberu-jin)
  • Norwegian:
    Bokmål: berbisk
    Nynorsk: berbisk
  • Polish: berberyjski (pl) m
  • Serbo-Croatian:
    Cyrillic: бѐрберскӣ
    Roman: bèrberskī (sh)
  • Tarifit: amaziɣ m, tamaziɣt f

See also

[edit]
  • Berberophone

Dutch

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

(This etymology is missing or incomplete. Please add to it, or discuss it at the Etymology scriptorium.)

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ˈbɛr.bər/
  • Audio:(file)
  • Hyphenation: Ber‧ber

Noun

[edit]

Berber m (plural Berbers, no diminutive)

  1. Berber, Berber person

Derived terms

[edit]
  • Berbers

Proper noun

[edit]

Berber n

  1. Berber, Berber languages

German

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ˈbɛrbər/, [ˈbɛʁ.bɐ], [ˈbɛɐ̯-]
  • Audio (Germany (Berlin)):(file)

Etymology 1

[edit]

Borrowed from French berbère, from Arabic بَرْبَر (barbar), from Ancient Greek βάρβαρος (bárbaros, “non-Greek”). Doublet of Barbar.

Noun

[edit]

Berber m (strong, genitive Berbers, plural Berber, feminine Berberin)

  1. Berber person
Declension
[edit]
Declension of Berber [masculine, strong]
singular plural
indef. def. noun def. noun
nominative ein der Berber die Berber
genitive eines des Berbers der Berber
dative einem dem Berber den Berbern
accusative einen den Berber die Berber
Derived terms
[edit]
  • berberisch
  • Berbersprache

Etymology 2

[edit]

Proper noun

[edit]

Berber m or f (proper noun, surname, masculine genitive Berbers or (with an article) Berber, feminine genitive Berber, plural Berbers or Berber)

  1. a surname

Serbo-Croatian

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /běrber/
  • Hyphenation: Ber‧ber

Noun

[edit]

Bèrber m anim (Cyrillic spelling Бѐрбер)

  1. Berber (member of the Berber ethnic group)

Declension

[edit]
Declension of Berber
singular plural
nominative Berber Berberi
genitive Berbera Berbera
dative Berberu Berberima
accusative Berbera Berbere
vocative Berberu Berberi
locative Berberu Berberima
instrumental Berberom Berberima

Derived terms

[edit]
  • bèrberskī
  • Bèrbērka
